Ministarstvo odbrane reagovalo na kritiku komesarke Saveta Evrope za ljudska prava

06 Nov 2019, 20:40

Ministarstvo odbrane je povodom izjave komesarke Saveta Evrope za ljudska prava Dunje Mijatović večeras saopštilo da se "u Srbiji knjige ne zabranjuju".Komesarka Saveta Evrope za ljudska prava, Dunja Mijatović, kritikovala je danas Ministarstvo odbrane Srbije zbog organizovanja promocije knjige "Tuzlanska kapija režirana tragedija" u kojoj se, kako je ukazala, "falsifikuju činjenice o zločinu" koji se 1995. dogodio u BiH."Ministarstvo odbrane izražava žaljenje jer je uvažena komesarka propustila da se oglasi kada je oslobodjen Naser Orić, dokazani ubica Srba, baš kao što nije uvidela potrebu da osudi i traži odgovornost za izjavu Emira Suljagića direktora Memorijalnog centra Potočari u Srebrenici u kojoj kaže da je 'Jasenovac četnička izmišljotina' i da su 'Časni bošnjaci iz Handžar divizije propustili priliku da reše četnike, zato nam je to ostavljeno u amanet' ", navodi se na sajtu ministarstva.Ministarstvo navodi da je "šteta što Dunja Mijatović ne traži da se sazna ko je u Srebrenici pokušao da ubije Aleksandra Vučića ili ko je lagao da se na Kosovu Šiptari truju jednonacionalnim otrovom iz Srbije"."Umesto da traga za istinom, Dunja Mijatović napada Ministarstvo odbrane zato što se u Domu Vojske raspravljalo o knjizi koju nije izdalo Ministarstvo odbrane. Svaki pokušaj drugačijeg vidjenja gradjanskog rata u BiH je veliki zločin ako dolazi od Srba. Ministarstvo odbrane na to neće pristati i zato je omogućilo da autor knjige i ljudi koji su učestvovali u istraživanju čitavog slučaja iznesu svoj stav", navode iz tog ministarstva.U tekstu objavljenom i na sajtu Ministarstva odbrane, navodi se i da su "Srbi mnogo puta bili i još uvek jesu žrtve dvostrukih standarda i često im se i sudilo i sudi za tudje zločine. Srbija neće zabranjivati knjige, to je tradicija nekih drugih naroda", te su preporučili komesarki da pročita knjigu koju je kritikovala.Lokalne grupe za ljudska prava i bošnjački zvaničnici takodje su kritikovali Ministarstvo odbrane Srbije zbog sinoćne promocije knjige Ilije Brankovića "Tuzlanska kapija režirana tragedija" u Domu Vojske Srbije.Mediji u BiH navode da se u toj knjizi osporava presuda Suda BiH kojom je Novak Djukić osudjen na 20 godina zatvora.

The Ministry of Defense reacted to the criticism of the Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights

06 Nov 2019, 19:40

The Ministry of Defense said on the statement of the Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights Dunja Mijatovic tonight that "books are not banned in Serbia." The Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights, Dunja Mijatovic, criticized the Serbian Ministry of Defense today for organizing the promotion of the book "Tuzla Gate Directed Tragedy" "which, she pointed out," forged facts about a crime "that happened in BiH in 1995." The Ministry of Defense regrets that the respected commissioner failed to appear when Naser Oric, a proven Serb killer, was released, just as he did not saw the need to condemn and demand responsibility for the statement of Emir Suljagic, director of the Potocari Memorial Center in Srebrenica, saying that 'Jasenovac is a Chetnik fabrication' and that 'Honorary Bosniaks from the Handzar Division missed the opportunity to solve the Chetniks, so we were left in the amanet' "The ministry's website states that" it is a pity Dunja Mijatovic is not looking for it and to find out who in Srebrenica tried to kill Aleksandar Vucic or who lied that in Kosovo, the Siptars were poisoned by mono-national poison from Serbia. "" Instead of searching for the truth, Dunja Mijatovic attacks the Ministry of Defense because a book was being discussed in the House of Commons. not issued by the Ministry of Defense. Any attempt to see the civil war in BiH differently is a great crime if it comes from Serbs. The Ministry of Defense will not agree to this, which is why it allowed the author of the book and the people who participated in the investigation of the whole case to express their views, "the ministry said. A text published on the Ministry of Defense's website also states that" were, and still are, victims of double standards, and were often tried and tried for other crimes. Serbia will not ban books, it is a tradition of some other nations, "and recommended that the commissioner read the book she criticized. Local human rights groups and Bosniak officials also criticized the Serbian Ministry of Defense for last night's promotion of Ilija Brankovic's book" Tuzla Gate Directed Tragedy " in the House of the Army of Serbia.The media in BiH state that the book challenges the judgment of the Court of BiH, sentencing Novak Djukic to 20 years in prison.
